name: Proseminar in American Literature, Prior to the Civil War
Introduction to Graduate Study in English and Comparative Literature
desc: This course introduces students to the field of literary studies in English and comparative literature. Students will survey a range of approaches, methods, and controversies that have emerged from the field. The focus on critical and institutional histories will provide a foundation for graduate work and for developing professional objectives.

name: Research Methods in Composition and Rhetoric
desc: Course introduces graduate students to methodologies of research in the field of Rhetoric and Composition. Emphasis is on theoretical and practical concerns that improve teaching and help develop research agendas.

name: Studies in Rhetoric and Composition
desc: Focus varies by semester, but generally investigates intersections of literacy, pedagogy, and rhetorical theory. Courses range from explorations of technology and literacy, to investigations of forms of writing and pedagogy.

name: History of the English Language
desc: Study of English from its Proto-Indo-European origins through the 18th century focusing on historic events and the major changes to the structure and usage of English they occasioned.

name: Seminar in Old English Language and Literature
desc: Topics in Old English poetry and prose that vary with each seminar and instructor.

name: Seminar in Middle English Literature
desc: Intensive study of major Middle English authors or genres or of medieval cultural influences. Topics have included Malory, Piers Plowman and its tradition, drama, and intellectual backgrounds of medieval literature.

name: Renaissance Literature in Context
desc: A study of select works of Renaissance literature, both dramatic and nondramatic, in its intellectual, social, political, or religious context.

name: Studies in Renaissance Authors
desc: Concentrated studies of single authors, groups of authors thematically linked, or authors in their families or coteries.

name: Perspectives on Renaissance Literature and Culture
desc: Students will study Renaissance literature while assessing the usefulness and status of a theoretical approach, such as feminist theory, queer theory, cultural materialism, new historicism, or psychoanalytic theory.

name: Studies in Renaissance Literature: Drama
desc: A study of Renaissance drama linked thematically, or framed by select cultural practices and historical issues.

name: Studies in Renaissance Literature: Primarily Nondramatic
desc: A focused examination of an aesthetic, historical, or theoretical problem in the study of Renaissance literature.

name: Seminar in 18th-Century Literature
desc: Selected topics in 18th-century literature.

name: 18th-Century Fiction
desc: Studies in eighteenth-century fiction from Behn to Austen.

name: Studies in English Literature, 1780-1832
desc: Sections: 1) Blake, Wordsworth, Coleridge, 2) Byron, Shelley, Keats. Examination of the major Romantic poets, supplemented by readings in other Romantic authors.

name: 19th-Century British Novel
desc: Examination of important 19th-century British novels, such as those by Austen, Scott, Dickens, the Brontes, sensation novelists, Gaskell, Carroll, Thackeray, Eliot, Trollope, Doyle, Hardy, Meredith.

name: Studies in Victorian Literature: Poetry
desc: Study of Victorian poets, focused on a group or a topic, including figures such as Tennyson, the Brownings, Arnold, and the Pre-Raphaelites.

name: Seminar in 19th-Century Romanticism in England
desc: Topics concerning major authors and issues of the Romantic period.

name: Seminar in Victorian Literature
desc: Topics concerning major authors and issues of the Victorian period.

name: Seminar in American Literature to 1860
desc: Topics vary: e.g., New England Puritanism, New England response to American literary nationalism; Emerson; Irving, Hawthorne, and Poe and the development of the American short story.

name: Seminar in American Literature, 1860-1900
desc: In-depth exploration for doctoral students of selected topics or authors in American Literature from 1860 to 1900.

name: Seminar in the American Novel
desc: Doctoral-level seminar in the selected topics or authors.

name: Studies in English and American Poetry of the 20th Century
desc: Usually taught as a survey of major poets: Yeats, Frost, Stevens, Williams, Pound, Eliot, Auden, with some more recent poets.

name: Seminar in Modern Drama
desc: Explores representative works of contemporary playwrights.

name: Studies in 20th-Century English and American Literature
desc: Studies in special modern and/or contemporary topics; e.g., the Irish literary renaissance, Latina/o Studies, Asian American Studies, cultural, visual culture, postcolonial, gender, and/or ethnic studies, and British and/or American Literature.

name: Studies in English and American Fiction of the 20th Century
desc: Usually taught as a survey of major writers: Joyce, Lawrence, Woolf, Hemingway, Faulkner, with some other writers.

name: Seminar in 20th-Century Literature, English and American
desc: Seminar examining issues in modern English and American Literature.

name: Seminar in Literary and Cultural Theory
desc: Seminar with varying topics, focusing on recent developments in literary and cultural theory, including narratology, feminism, psychoanalysis, and postcolonial and materialist theory.

name: Seminar in Cultural Studies
desc: Advanced exploration of myriad tests, topics, controversies, institutions, and personalities that make up the ongoing knowledge projects that are loosely affiliated under the rubric 'cultural studies.'

name: Seminar in Postcolonial Literature
desc: Course examines the shifting meanings of postcoloniality in 20th- and 21st- century literature from formerly colonized countries.

name: Studies in Latina/o Literature, Culture, and Criticism
desc: Representative work by Latina/o writers and critics in relation to major social and historical trends and critical models-border theory, biculturalism, mestizaje, tropicalization, diaspora, pan-latinidad, Afro-Latina/o disidentifications, and LatinAsia Studies.

name: African American and African Diasporan Literature, 1930-1970
desc: Key writers within the context of selected literary, cultural, and critical traditions from 1930 to 1970.

name: Seminar in African American Literature
desc: An intensive study of a major writer or text, a group of writers or texts, or an important trend, tradition, or literary period.

name: Studies in African American and African Diasporan Literature
desc: An intensive study of a particular aspect of African American literature, such as speculative fiction, subject formation, comparative diasporan literatures, gender issues, theoretical and critical approaches, or formal innovations.

name: Literature of the U
desc: An in-depth treatment of selected topics (e.g., the Southern Renaissance, postmodern southern fiction, the racial conversion narrative) in Southern literature.

name: Critical Race Theory-Graduate Seminar
desc: Seminar examines and engages with critical race theory and the various texts (narrative, cultural productions) that are in conversation with theories of race and that reflect representations of race.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 2 total completions.

name: Introduction to Modern Irish I
desc: An introduction to modern Irish grammar.

name: Introduction to Modern Irish II
desc: Readings in Modern Irish Literature.
Prereqs: Prerequisite, ENGL 876.

name: Ireland in Modernity
desc: This course will examine the relationships between Irish writing, culture, and modernism, in the context of international developments in literature and art.

name: Studies in Cinema
desc: This course offers graduate students the opportunity to investigate, in a seminar setting, a particular subject within the domain of film studies.

name: Seminar in Ecological Theory and Practice
desc: In-depth evaluation of ecological theory, ecocritical pedagogy, and literary criticism.

name: Directed Readings
desc: Topics vary according to the needs and interests of the individual student and the professor directing the reading and writing project.
Repeat: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics.
